channel.title: Update server illegal?
channel.description: When a server has an update server would that like go against copyright? This includes modifying it or not since I've seen some kids has like "custom crowns" and bitch to me saying they're smart ass fucks that know what they're doing (lol >.<)

item.title: Update server illegal?
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:11, topic:523097”][quote author=Fire capez link=topic=641614.msg4322300#msg4322300 date=1372367188]

Anything remotely related to rsps is illegaly. Nuff said.

That’s not really true at all. If I write a server that accepts the RS client’s protocol and sends relevant data back, it is entirely my work. The fact that it can be used as an emulation tool is irrelevant, JaGeX own the client and the cache but they do not own the server (they also do not own the file format).

protocol is intellectual property IIRC

Really? I thought that the only issue with that was that the Stream class belonged to JaGeX.

I don’t think they could press charges on the protocol itself since it isn’t very complex, however they may be able to on the account that you would have to have had access to the client to write the server protocol in the first place.
[/quote]

Reverse engineering the client is against their ToS but I don’t think there’s any laws against viewing deobfuscated source code, is there?[/quote]

Their TOS isn’t a legal binding so it’s irrelevant in legal matters, as for deobfuscated I don’t know of the laws in other countries but in the UK we have a statue that allows us to view source code providing it isn’t used to make a project of a similar nature to provide evidence I shall quote the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988:

"
F450B Decompilation.(1)It is not an infringement of copyright for a lawful user of a copy of a computer program expressed in a low level language—
(a)to convert it into a version expressed in a higher level language, or
(b)incidentally in the course of so converting the program, to copy it,
(that is, to “decompile” it), provided that the conditions in subsection (2) are met.
(2)The conditions are that—
(a)it is necessary to decompile the program to obtain the information necessary to create an independent program which can be operated with the program decompiled or with another program (“the permitted objective”); and
(b)the information so obtained is not used for any purpose other than the permitted objective.
(3)In particular, the conditions in subsection (2) are not met if the lawful user—
(a)has readily available to him the information necessary to achieve the permitted objective;
(b)does not confine the decompiling to such acts as are necessary to achieve the permitted objective;
©supplies the information obtained by the decompiling to any person to whom it is not necessary to supply it in order to achieve the permitted objective; or
buses the information to create a program which is substantially similar in its expression to the program decompiled or to do any act restricted by copyright.[/b]
(4)Where an act is permitted under this section, it is irrelevant whether or not there exists any term or condition in an agreement which purports to prohibit or restrict the act (such terms being, by virtue of section 296A, void).
"

Read full topic

item.title: Update server illegal?
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“Fire capez, post:10, topic:523097”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=641614.msg4322279#msg4322279 date=1372365900]

Anything remotely related to rsps is illegaly. Nuff said.

That’s not really true at all. If I write a server that accepts the RS client’s protocol and sends relevant data back, it is entirely my work. The fact that it can be used as an emulation tool is irrelevant, JaGeX own the client and the cache but they do not own the server (they also do not own the file format).

protocol is intellectual property IIRC

Really? I thought that the only issue with that was that the Stream class belonged to JaGeX.
[/quote]

I don’t think they could press charges on the protocol itself since it isn’t very complex, however they may be able to on the account that you would have to have had access to the client to write the server protocol in the first place.[/quote]

Reverse engineering the client is against their ToS but I don’t think there’s any laws against viewing deobfuscated source code, is there?

Read full topic
